member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.Button
member.summary: Connect a manager control to a Button control to specify that the button performs a common user interface command, such as Open Sequence File. The Button control uses a localized caption and automatically enables or disables depending on the application state.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.MouseIcon
member.summary: Specifies the custom mouse icon for the control.
member.remarks:
The control displays the specified picture as the cursor when the value of the Button.MousePointer property is MousePointer_Custom. When you set this property to NULL, the value of the Button.MousePointer property changes to MousePointer_Default.
Note: This property requires that the picture value is an icon.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.MouseIcon

Note: This property requires that the picture value is an icon.

member.summary: Specifies the font for the control when the value of the Button.FontSource property is FontSource_UseFontProperty.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.Font
member.summary: Specifies the font for the control when the value of the Button.FontSource property is FontSource_UseFontProperty.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.Caption
member.summary: Specifies the text the control displays.
member.remarks: In the caption, include an ampersand (&) immediately before the character, if any, you want to designate as an accelerator character. The character displays as underlined. Press <Alt> and the underlined character to move the focus to the control. To include an ampersand character in a caption without creating an accelerator character, include two consecutive ampersands. A single ampersand displays in the caption and no characters display as underlined. When you connect this control to a manager control, the manager control sets this property automatically.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.Caption

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.Value
member.summary: This property is True when the button is pressed and False when the button is not pressed. Use this property when the value of the ButtonActionStyles enumeration is ButtonActionStyle_ToggleButton to set the pressed state of the button.
member.remarks:
Setting this property generates a Button.Click event.
Note: You cannot set this property at design time.

member.summary: Occurs when the user clicks the mouse on the control. This event occurs before the Button.MouseUp event.

Specifies a combination of the KeyModifiers constants that specifies the state of the <Shift>, <Ctrl>, and <Alt> keys.
Specifies the x-coordinate of the mouse pointer, relative to the control, at the moment when the event occurs.
Specifies the y-coordinate of the mouse pointer, relative to the control, at the moment when the event occurs.

member.summary: Occurs when the user releases the mouse button on the control. This event occurs before the Button.Click event.

Specifies a combination of the KeyModifiers constants that specifies the state of the <Shift>, <Ctrl>, and <Alt> keys.
Specifies the x-coordinate of the mouse pointer, relative to the control, at the moment when the event occurs.
Specifies the y-coordinate of the mouse pointer, relative to the control, at the moment when the event occurs.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the text caption on the button in this control.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the caption for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the caption with the string from the .ini file. If the caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect this control to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the text caption on the button in this control.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the caption for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the caption with the string from the .ini file. If the caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect this control to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the Button.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the Button.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IButton.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface Controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonClass.ScaleWithDPI

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEdit
member.summary: Use an ExpressionEdit control so users can edit a TestStand expression with syntax coloring, popup help, and statement completion. Although you typically do not need to edit expressions in a user interface application, you can connect a manager control to a read-only ExpressionEdit control to display text information about the application state, such as the pathname of the sequence file selection or the name of the current user. You can also use ExpressionEdit controls in dialog boxes for step types and in tools in which you prompt users to enter a TestStand expression.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.SetAdditionalEvaluationConstants(System.Object[])
member.summary: Use this method to specify additional constants that the expression can contain that are not part of the Context. The ExpressionEdit control does not consider an identifier that has the same name as one of these constants as an error.
member.remarks: This method is useful when the expression can contain a constant from an enumeration, such as a parameter value of a module call when the type of that parameter is an enumeration.
member.param: Specifies variables that are valid in the expression but are not part of the context. For example, include a numeric or string PropertyObject where the name and value of the object are the name and value of the enumeration or constant. The control ignores subproperties of the object.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.SetAdditionalEvaluationConstants(System.Object[])

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.CreateContextMenu
member.summary: Occurs just before the ExpressionEdit control displays its context menu. Use this event to add or remove items from the context menu of the ExpressionEdit control.
member.remarks: The ExpressionEdit control creates a new context menu every time it displays its context menu to the user.
member.param:
Specifies the Microsoft Windows menu handle (HMENU) of the context menu. Use menu functions in the Windows Software Development Kit to modify this menu. Use the ExpressionEdit.ContextMenuItemClick event to respond to the user clicking menu items you add.
When the context menu closes, the control disposes of the menu items. Thus, you do not need to dispose of menu items you insert.
Specifies where the left edge of the context menu is visible, relative to the control.
Specifies where the top edge of the context menu is visible, relative to the control.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.ContextMenuItemClick
member.summary: Occurs when the user selects a menu item from the ExpressionEdit control context menu.
member.param: Specifies the menu item ID of the menu item the user selects.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.ContextChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the ExpressionEdit.Context property changes.
member.param: Specifies how the ExpressionEdit.Context property changed.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.CheckExpression
member.summary: Occurs when the control checks the expression for errors.
member.remarks: The initial values of the event parameters indicate whether the control detected an error in the expression. Use the event to evaluate, modify, or ignore the error or to perform and report additional expression checking on the expression.
member.param: Specifies the error code for an error that exists in the expression.
Specifies the error description for an error that exists in the expression.
Specifies the starting index of the error when an error exists in the expression.
Specifies one character past the ending index of the error when an error exists in the expression.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.Engine
member.summary:
Specifies a reference to the Engine object. The ExpressionEdit control uses the Engine object for the following purposes:
* Displaying the Expression Browser dialog box.
* Displaying the Expression Editing Options dialog box, which you can access through the Options item in the context menu of the ExpressionEdit control.
* Reading options configured in the Expression Editing Options dialog box.
member.remarks: You do not need to set this property because the ExpressionEdit control automatically obtains a reference to an Engine object when a reference is needed. However, because the ExpressionEdit control creates an Engine object when it cannot obtain one from the ExpressionEdit.Context property, it is useful to set this property when the ExpressionEdit.Context property has not been set to a PropertyObject that is also a SequenceContext and when an Engine object has already been created in a different process than the ExpressionEdit control. The TestStand Engine is considered needed when the ExpressionEdit.Context property is set or when this property is read, even when the property is read internally to launch an engine dialog box.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.Engine
member.summary:
Specifies a reference to the Engine object. The ExpressionEdit control uses the Engine object for the following purposes:
* Displaying the Expression Browser dialog box.
* Displaying the Expression Editing Options dialog box, which you can access through the Options item in the context menu of the ExpressionEdit control.
* Reading options configured in the Expression Editing Options dialog box.
member.remarks: You do not need to set this property because the ExpressionEdit control automatically obtains a reference to an Engine object when a reference is needed. However, because the ExpressionEdit control creates an Engine object when it cannot obtain one from the ExpressionEdit.Context property, it is useful to set this property when the ExpressionEdit.Context property has not been set to a PropertyObject that is also a SequenceContext and when an Engine object has already been created in a different process than the ExpressionEdit control. The TestStand Engine is considered needed when the ExpressionEdit.Context property is set or when this property is read, even when the property is read internally to launch an engine dialog box.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.Context
member.summary: Specifies the set of available variables and properties for autocompletion, error checking, evaluation, and the Expression Browser dialog box. Set this property to a PropertyObject in which the expression you are editing can be evaluated.
member.remarks: The ExpressionEdit control might create an Engine object when you set the Context to a PropertyObject that is not a SequenceContext. Refer to the ExpressionEdit.Engine property for more information about creating a reference to an Engine object.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.WantReturn
member.summary:
Specifies whether the ExpressionEdit control processes the <Enter> key. When the ExpressionEdit control is not processing the <Enter> key, the <Enter> key goes to the default button.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_False, the <Enter> key goes to the default button.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_True, the control applies the <Enter> key to the expression.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_UsePreference, the Want Return option in the Expression Editing Options dialog box determines the setting.
member.remarks: If the ExpressionEdit.Multiline property is False, this property is ignored and the <Enter> key is never processed.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.WantReturn
member.summary:
Specifies whether the ExpressionEdit control processes the <Enter> key. When the ExpressionEdit control is not processing the <Enter> key, the <Enter> key goes to the default button.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_False, the <Enter> key goes to the default button.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_True, the control applies the <Enter> key to the expression.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_UsePreference, the Want Return option in the Expression Editing Options dialog box determines the setting.
member.remarks: If the ExpressionEdit.Multiline property is False, this property is ignored and the <Enter> key is never processed.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.WordWrap
member.summary:
Specifies that lines too long to display on one line wrap to the next line.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_False, word wrap is off.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_True, word wrap is on.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_UsePreference, the Word Wrap option in the Expression Editing Options dialog box determines whether word wrap is on.
member.remarks: When the ExpressionEdit.Multiline property is False, this property is ignored.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.WordWrap
member.summary:
Specifies that lines too long to display on one line wrap to the next line.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_False, word wrap is off.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_True, word wrap is on.
* When the value of this property is BooleanOrPreference_UsePreference, the Word Wrap option in the Expression Editing Options dialog box determines whether word wrap is on.
member.remarks: When the ExpressionEdit.Multiline property is False, this property is ignored.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.AllowEmpty
member.summary: TestStand returns an error for an empty expression only when this property is False.
member.remarks: The ExpressionEdit control displays the text "<The expression cannot be empty>" when this property is False, the control contains an empty expression, the control is not active, and error checking is enabled.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.AllowEmpty

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck
member.summary: Specifies whether the control performs error checking on the expression. When the value of this property is a value other than ErrorCheck_None, the expression is checked for errors when the ExpressionEdit control loses focus, when you select Check for Errors from the context menu, or when the ExpressionEdit.DisplayError method is called.
member.remarks: When an error is found, the error is displayed in a different font color or style. The error message is displayed in a tooltip.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.ErrorCheck
member.summary: Specifies whether the control performs error checking on the expression. When the value of this property is a value other than ErrorCheck_None, the expression is checked for errors when the ExpressionEdit control loses focus, when you select Check for Errors from the context menu, or when the ExpressionEdit.DisplayError method is called.
member.remarks: When an error is found, the error is displayed in a different font color or style. The error message is displayed in a tooltip.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.RequiredTypes

summary.para: Note: This property is obsolete. Use the ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes and ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes methods instead.

member.remarks: Specifies any combination of the ValidExpressionTypes constants. Use the bitwise-OR operator to specify more than one valid type. Specifies the allowed evaluation result types when the value of the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck property is ErrorCheck_SyntaxAndEvaluation. If the value of this property is ValidExpressionType_NamedType or ValidExpressionType_NamedTypeArray, the named types or named type arrays must be specified using the RequiredNamedTypes property and the RequiredNamedTypeArrays property, respectively.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.RequiredTypes

summary.para: Note: This property is obsolete. Use the ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes and ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes methods instead.

member.remarks: Specifies any combination of the ValidExpressionTypes constants. Use the bitwise-OR operator to specify more than one valid type. Specifies the allowed evaluation result types when the value of the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck property is ErrorCheck_SyntaxAndEvaluation. If the value of this property is ValidExpressionType_NamedType or ValidExpressionType_NamedTypeArray, the named types or named type arrays must be specified using the RequiredNamedTypes property and the RequiredNamedTypeArrays property, respectively.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.RequiredNamedTypes

summary.para: Note: This property is obsolete. Use the ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes and ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes methods instead.

member.remarks: Returns a collection of strings that specify the named types that are allowed when the value of the ExpressionEdit.RequiredTypes property is ValidExpressionType_NamedType. The ExpressionEdit control highlights the expression as an evaluation error when the expression fails to evaluate to a named type listed in the collection.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.CheckExpression(System.String@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the result of the error checking the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck, ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes, and ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes methods specify.
member.remarks: When you call this method, the ExpressionEdit control might modify the text to automatically prefix variables that do not have a full path specified. Calling this method does not display an error. To display an error, call the ExpressionEdit.DisplayError method.
member.returns: An error code.
member.param: When an error exists, this parameter returns an error message that describes the error.
When an error exists, this parameter returns the starting character index of the error in the expression.
When an error exists, this parameter returns the index of one character past the ending character index of the error in the expression.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.CheckExpression(System.String@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the result of the error checking the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck, ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes, and ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes methods specify.
member.remarks: When you call this method, the ExpressionEdit control might modify the text to automatically prefix variables that do not have a full path specified. Calling this method does not display an error. To display an error, call the ExpressionEdit.DisplayError method.
member.returns: An error code.
member.param: When an error exists, this parameter returns an error message that describes the error.
When an error exists, this parameter returns the starting character index of the error in the expression.
When an error exists, this parameter returns the index of one character past the ending character index of the error in the expression.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.DisplayError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs error checking the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck and ExpressionEdit.AllowEmpty properties and the ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes and ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes methods specify. The ExpressionEdit control displays any errors in a different font and displays the error message in a tooltip.
member.remarks: Use this method to force the ExpressionEdit control to check for errors as it does when you select Check for Errors from the ExpressionEdit control context menu. When you call this method, the ExpressionEdit control might modify the text to automatically prefix variables that do not have a full path specified.
member.param: Specifies a bitwise-OR combination of the DisplayErrorOptions constants.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.DisplayError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs error checking the ExpressionEdit.ErrorCheck and ExpressionEdit.AllowEmpty properties and the ExpressionEdit.SetValidEvaluationTypes and ExpressionEdit.GetValidEvaluationTypes methods specify. The ExpressionEdit control displays any errors in a different font and displays the error message in a tooltip.
member.remarks: Use this method to force the ExpressionEdit control to check for errors as it does when you select Check for Errors from the ExpressionEdit control context menu. When you call this method, the ExpressionEdit control might modify the text to automatically prefix variables that do not have a full path specified.
member.param: Specifies a bitwise-OR combination of the DisplayErrorOptions constants.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.Evaluate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates the current expression using the context the ExpressionEdit.Context property specifies.
member.returns: The result of the evaluation.
member.param: Pass Eval_NoOptions to specify the default behavior, or pass one or more EvaluationOptions constants. The EvalOption_AllowEmptyExpression constant is ignored. Use the ExpressionEdit.AllowEmpty property to determine whether to treat an empty expression as an error. Use the bitwise-OR operator to specify multiple options.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.Evaluate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates the current expression using the context the ExpressionEdit.Context property specifies.
member.returns: The result of the evaluation.
member.param: Pass Eval_NoOptions to specify the default behavior, or pass one or more EvaluationOptions constants. The EvalOption_AllowEmptyExpression constant is ignored. Use the ExpressionEdit.AllowEmpty property to determine whether to treat an empty expression as an error. Use the bitwise-OR operator to specify multiple options.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.ReadOnly
member.summary: Specifies that the control can be edited.

member.summary: Specifies that the control can be edited.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the current font for the ExpressionEdit control. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont. When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the ExpressionEdit.Font property specifies the current font.
member.remarks: Only the font name and size are used. All other properties of this parameter are ignored because the other properties are set on a per-text element basis in the Expression Editing Options dialog box, which you can access through the Options item from the context menu of the ExpressionEdit control. When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the ExpressionEdit.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the current font for the ExpressionEdit control. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont. When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the ExpressionEdit.Font property specifies the current font.
member.remarks: Only the font name and size are used. All other properties of this parameter are ignored because the other properties are set on a per-text element basis in the Expression Editing Options dialog box, which you can access through the Options item from the context menu of the ExpressionEdit control. When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the ExpressionEdit.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.TextType
member.summary: Use this property to make an ExpressionEdit control behave like an ordinary edit or text box control. This is useful when you want to use an edit control for editing expressions and plain text.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.BrowseExprDialogClosed
member.summary: Occurs when you close an Expression Browser dialog box displayed using the Browse menu item in the ExpressionEdit control context menu or the ExpressionEdit.DisplayBrowseExprDialog method.
member.param: This parameter is True when you click OK in the Expression Browser dialog box and False when you click Cancel.

This parameter is True when a variable or property in the context is created, deleted, or renamed through the context menu in the Expression Browser dialog box while the Expression Browser dialog box is displayed. This parameter is False when the user modifies only the value of a variable or property.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface Controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.ScaleWithDPI

* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.BorderDragged
member.summary: Occurs when the user drags a draggable border of a control with the mouse. The event provides the location and size to which you must set the control for the draggable borders to track the mouse cursor. However, you can choose to modify the location or size to which you set the control. For example, you can limit the width of the control so the left edge cannot be dragged off the visible portion of the window. In addition to changing the size and position of the control, you might also update the sizes and positions of the other controls on the window to account for the change.
member.remarks: If you are using LabVIEW, you must add the Horizontal and Vertical components of the origin of the LabVIEW front panel to the newX and newY event parameter values before you can use the newX and newY event parameters to set the ActiveX Container (AxCont) Left and Top properties for the control. To obtain the origin of a LabVIEW front panel, place an ActiveX property node on the block diagram of the VI, right-click the node, and select Link to»Pane from the context menu. Right-click the node again and select Select Property»Origin.
member.param: Specifies which borders the user dragged. Refer to the WhichBorders constants for more information about draggable borders.
Specifies the new x-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new y-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new width for the control.
Specifies the new height for the control.
Specifies whether the event is the final event for the drag operation the user performs.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IExpressionEdit.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties for each ExpressionEditButton and the DisplayName property of each ExpressionEditComboBoxItem.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties of each button and the DisplayName property of each combo box item. When you call this method, the control replaces the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties of each button and the DisplayName property of each combo box item with the string from the .ini file. If the ToolTipText, ContextMenuItemCaption, or DisplayName property is not a tag in the .ini file, the property does not change.
Note: This method does not localize the ToolTipText of non-custom buttons. Non-custom buttons localize ToolTipText automatically.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ExpressionEditClass.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties for each ExpressionEditButton and the DisplayName property of each ExpressionEditComboBoxItem.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties of each button and the DisplayName property of each combo box item. When you call this method, the control replaces the ToolTipText and ContextMenuItemCaption properties of each button and the DisplayName property of each combo box item with the string from the .ini file. If the ToolTipText, ContextMenuItemCaption, or DisplayName property is not a tag in the .ini file, the property does not change.
Note: This method does not localize the ToolTipText of non-custom buttons. Non-custom buttons localize ToolTipText automatically.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.InsertComboBoxItem
member.summary: Occurs when the user selects an item in the drop-down list. This event is useful when you do not want the selected item to replace the existing text.
member.remarks: You cannot use this event to change what text to insert into the ExpressionEdit control.
member.param: Specifies the item to insert into the ExpressionEdit control.

Specifies the zero-based index of the character where the selected item is inserted. This parameter is initialized to zero. You can change the value of this parameter to change where the selected item is inserted.

Specifies the zero-based index of the last character the selected item replaces. This parameter is initialized to the index of the last character in the ExpressionEdit control. You can change the value of this parameter to change what text the selected item replaces.

Use this property when you use the ExpressionEdit control with expression strings that are already localized for display. member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ExpressionEditEvents_Event.BrowseExprDialogOpened
member.summary: Occurs just before the ExpressionEdit control displays the Expression Browser dialog box. Use this event to override the default parameter values the ExpressionEdit control passes to the Expression Browser dialog box or to cancel displaying the Expression Browser dialog box to the user.
member.param: Specifies the title of the Expression Browser dialog box. Assign a value to this parameter to override the default title.
Specifies the BrowseExprDialogOptions the ExpressionEdit control passes to the Expression Browser dialog box. Assign a value to this parameter to override the default options.
Specifies the zero-based character index where selection begins. Assign a value to this parameter to override the default start of selection.
Specifies the zero-based character index where selection ends. Assign a value to this parameter to override the default end of selection.

Specifies the name of the initial variable or property to show as selected in the tree view portion of the Expression Browser dialog box. Assign a value to this parameter to override the default initially selected variable. Assign an empty string to this parameter to select the first item.
Assign True to this parameter to prevent the ExpressionEdit control from displaying the Expression Browser dialog box to the user.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage
member.summary: Connect a SequenceFileView Manager or ExecutionView Manager control to a ListBarPage object so users can iterate through the items in the page and set the cursor, caption, and name of the page. Use the ListBarPages.Insert method to create a new ListBarPage object. Use the ListBarPage.Cursor property to determine the selected item in the page. Use the ListBarPage control to connect to and display the ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ExecutionList, ExecutionViewMgrConnections.CallStack, and ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ThreadList properties in the ExecutionView Manager control and the SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceList, SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceFileList, and SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.StepGroupList properties in the SequenceFileView Manager control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Items
member.summary: Returns a collection of items on the page.
member.remarks: Use this property to obtain a ListBarPageItems collection, which you can use to iterate through all the items on the page.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Cursor
member.summary: Specifies the zero-based index of the item the cursor selects.
member.remarks: Use this property to obtain the position of the cursor or move the cursor on the page.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Name
member.summary: Specifies the name of the ListBarPage.
member.remarks: Every ListBarPage must have a unique name, which can be used to identify the ListBarPage within the ListBarPages collection. ListBarPage names are not case-sensitive.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Index
member.summary: Returns the numeric zero-based index of the page within the ListBarPages collection.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Caption
member.summary: Specifies the caption text of the page.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPage.Enabled
member.summary: Specifies to enable or disable the ListBarPage.
member.remarks: Users cannot move the cursor when the page is disabled.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages
member.summary: A collection of ListBarPage objects. Use the ListBar.Pages property to retrieve the ListBarPages object for a ListBar. Use the ListBar.CurrentPage property as an index to this collection to access the currently selected page.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages.Item(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a reference to an item with the specified name or at the specified index in the collection.
member.param: You can pass a number to obtain a page by its zero-based index. You can also pass a string to obtain the ListBarPage using its name.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of items in the collection.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages.Insert(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a new item to the collection and returns a reference to the new ListBarPage.
member.param: Specifies the name for the new ListBarPage. ListBarPage names must be unique. ListBarPage names are not case-sensitive.
Specifies the index of the existing ListBarPage before which the new ListBarPage is inserted. To insert the new ListBarPage at the end, pass -1 to this parameter.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages.Remove(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the specified item from this collection, if it exists.
member.param: Pass the zero-based index for the page to remove.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarPages.Clear
member.summary: Removes all items from the collection.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBar
member.summary: Use a ListBar control to display multiple pages, where each page contains a list of items users can view or select. Connect a SequenceFileView Manager or ExecutionView Manager control to a ListBar page so users can view and select from a list, such as the active sequence file or execution. Connect an Application Manager control to a ListBar page so users can view or select the default adapter of the TestStand Engine. You can view the contents of a page by clicking on the page node, and you can also select a single item with the current page. Use the ListBar.CurrentPage property to determine the selected page, and use Pages.Item(CurrentPage).Cursor to determine the selected item on the current page.

You can view the contents of a page by clicking on the page node, and you can also select a single item with the current page. Use the ListBar.CurrentPage property to determine the selected page, and use Pages.Item(CurrentPage).Cursor to determine the selected item on the current page.

member.summary: Localizes the captions of all pages.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the caption for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the caption with the string from the .ini file. If the caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect a page to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized page caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarClass.Localize(System.String)

member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBar.ButtonFontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty if you expect the font the ListBar.ButtonFont property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBar.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface Controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarClass.ScaleWithDPI

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ListBarEvents_Event.CreateContextMenu
member.summary: Occurs when the user right-clicks the control so the application can build a context menu from which the user can select commands. Although you can implement context menus in most environments without using this event, some environments do not provide any other way to create a context menu. Also, creating a context menu using this event can be simpler in most environments, especially when the context menu contains only TestStand commands.
member.param: Specifies the Microsoft Windows menu handle (HMENU). When you add menu items to the menu handle, the control displays them in a context menu. Use the Commands.InsertIntoWin32Menu method to insert TestStand commands to the menu. You can also use the menu functions in the Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) to add other menu items. Menu items you add this way do not have an associated TestStand command. When the user selects an item that does not have a TestStand command, the control creates and executes a Command object of kind CommandKind_Custom. The control stores the menu item identifier (resource ID/command ID) as a long in the Command.UserData property and as a decimal string in the command display name. You can handle either the ApplicationMgr.PreCommandExecute or ApplicationMgr.PostCommandExecute event to receive a notification when the user selects a menu item you insert with the Windows SDK. When the context menu closes, the control disposes of the menu items. Thus, you do not need to dispose of menu items you insert.
Specifies the horizontal position of the right-mouse click, relative to the control.
Specifies the vertical position of the right-mouse click, relative to the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBar.Borders
member.summary: Returns the frame and draggable borders that surround the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBarClass.Borders
member.summary: Returns the frame and draggable borders that surround the control.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ListBarEvents_Event.BorderDragged
member.summary: Occurs when the user drags a draggable border of a control with the mouse. The event provides the location and size to which you must set the control for the draggable borders to track the mouse cursor. However, you can choose to modify the location or size to which you set the control. For example, you can limit the width of the control so the left edge cannot be dragged off of the visible portion of the window. In addition to changing the size and position of the control, you might also update the sizes and positions of the other controls on the window to account for the change.
member.remarks: If you are using LabVIEW, you must add the Horizontal and Vertical components of the origin of the LabVIEW front panel to the newX and newY event parameter values before you can use the newX and newY event parameters to set the ActiveX Container (AxCont) Left and Top properties for the control. To obtain the origin of a LabVIEW front panel, place an ActiveX property node on the block diagram of the VI, right-click the node, and select Link to»Pane from the context menu. Right-click the node again and select Select Property»Origin.
member.param: Specifies which borders the user dragged. Refer to the WhichBorders constants for more information about draggable borders.
Specifies the new x-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new y-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new width for the control.
Specifies the new height for the control.
Specifies whether the event is the final event for the drag operation the user performs.

Specifies the index of the ListBarPage to which the connection made a change.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane
member.summary: Represents a status bar pane.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width for the pane in pixels.
member.remarks: When you set the StatusBarPane.UseAvailableSpace property to True, the specified width of the pane is ignored when the StatusBar pane is the leftmost visible StatusBar pane with a True value for the StatusBarPane.UseAvailableSpace property.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.ToolTipText
member.summary: Specifies the tooltip for a status bar pane. When this property is an empty string, the pane uses the StatusBarPane.Caption property for the tooltip.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Name
member.summary: Specifies the name for the pane.
member.remarks: Every pane must have a unique name, which can be used to identify the pane within the StatusBarPanes collection. Pane names are not case-sensitive.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Style
member.summary: Specifies the appearance of the pane.
member.remarks: A StatusBar pane can have only one style.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.ProcessPercent
member.summary: Specifies a number between 0 and 100 to determine the progress for the StatusBar pane. The StatusBar pane uses this number to draw a progress bar.
member.remarks:
You can combine a caption, image, and progress bar on the same StatusBar pane. Set ProcessPercent to 0 when you do not want the StatusBar pane to contain a progress bar.
Note: When a StatusBar pane is connected to a numeric source of a manager control, you cannot change the process percent.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Caption
member.summary: Specifies the caption for the StatusBar pane.
member.remarks:
You can display a caption and progress bar on the same StatusBar pane.
Note: When you connect a StatusBar pane to the caption source of a manager control, you cannot change the caption. When you connect a StatusBar pane to the image source of a manager control, the caption does not display when you display an image. Additionally, the caption does not display when you use the StatusBarPane.IconName property to specify a valid icon.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Index
member.summary: Returns the zero-based index of the pane in the StatusBarPanes collection.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.TextAlignment
member.summary: Specifies the alignment of the caption text.
member.remarks: This method also applies to images when the StatusBar control is used to display images.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.Visible
member.summary: Specifies whether the StatusBar pane is visible.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.IconName
member.summary: Specifies an icon for the StatusBar pane.
member.remarks:
TestStand User Interface Controls use icons from the <TestStand>\Components\Icons and <TestStand Public>\Components\Icons directories. To specify an icon for a StatusBar pane, pass the name of the .ico file to this property.
Note: When a StatusBar pane is connected to an image source of a manager control, you cannot change the icon.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane.UseAvailableSpace
member.summary: Set this property to True when you want a StatusBar pane to occupy all available space in the status bar not used by other panes. This property enables a pane to adjust to make full use of the available space when the status bar changes size.
member.remarks: Although you can have more than one StatusBar pane with a value of True for this property, only the leftmost visible StatusBar pane honors this setting.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPanes
member.summary: A collection of StatusBarPane objects.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPanes.Item(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a reference to an item with the specified name or at the specified index in the collection.
member.param: Specifies a number to obtain a StatusBar pane by the zero-based index. Pass a string to obtain the StatusBar pane using the name.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPanes.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of items in the collection.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPanes.Insert(NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.StatusBarPane,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a new item to the collection and returns the new StatusBarPane object.
member.returns: Specifies the new StatusBar pane.
member.param: Specifies the name of the new StatusBar pane. This name must be unique and is not case-sensitive.

member.param: Specifies a number to remove a StatusBar pane by the zero-based index. Pass a string to remove a StatusBar pane using the name.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IStatusBar.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes all the text captions in the StatusBar control.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the <TestStand Public>\Components\Language directory with the required strings. Second, use the string tags in the .ini file as the pane captions for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the pane captions with the strings from the .ini file. If a caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect a pane to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

Specifies the y-coordinate of the location to test, in pixels, relative to the control.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ComboBox
member.summary:
Connect a SequenceFileView Manager or ExecutionView Manager control to a ComboBox control so users can view or select from a list of sequence files, sequences, step groups, steps, executions, threads, or stack frames. Connect an Application Manager control to a ComboBox control so users can view or select the default adapter of the TestStand Engine. Use the ComboBox control to connect to and display the ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ExecutionList, ExecutionViewMgrConnections.CallStack, and ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ThreadList properties in the ExecutionView Manager control and the SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceList, SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceFileList, and SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.StepGroupList properties in the SequenceFileView Manager control. Selecting an item in the ComboBox control updates the application based on the type of data the connection specifies.
Note: The ComboBox control does not allow you to populate the items in the drop-down list without connecting to a list connection. The items in the drop-down list are obtained from the connection to a manager control.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IComboBox
member.summary:
Connect a SequenceFileView Manager or ExecutionView Manager control to a ComboBox control so users can view or select from a list of sequence files, sequences, step groups, steps, executions, threads, or stack frames. Connect an Application Manager control to a ComboBox control so users can view or select the default adapter of the TestStand Engine. Use the ComboBox control to connect to and display the ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ExecutionList, ExecutionViewMgrConnections.CallStack, and ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ThreadList properties in the ExecutionView Manager control and the SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceList, SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceFileList, and SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.StepGroupList properties in the SequenceFileView Manager control. Selecting an item in the ComboBox control updates the application based on the type of data the connection specifies.
Note: The ComboBox control does not allow you to populate the items in the drop-down list without connecting to a list connection. The items in the drop-down list are obtained from the connection to a manager control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IComboBox.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the ComboBox.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ComboBoxClass.FontSource

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IComboBox.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ComboBoxClass.ScaleWithDPI

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonSizing
member.summary: Use these constants with the Button.AutoSizing property.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonSizing.ButtonSizing_AlwaysAutoSize
member.summary: (Value: 0) Always resize the Button control to fit the text.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonSizing.ButtonSizing_GrowOnly
member.summary: (Value: 1) Resize the Button control only when the text does not fit in the control.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonSizing.ButtonSizing_ShrinkOnly
member.summary: (Value: 2) Resize the Button control only when the text is smaller than the button.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ButtonSizing.ButtonSizing_NeverAutoSize
member.summary: (Value: 3) Never resize the Button control.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ReloadFiles
member.summary: Use these constants with the ApplicationMgr.ReloadSequenceFilesOnStart property.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ReloadFiles.ReloadFile_None
member.summary: (Value: 0) Does not reload any files.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ReloadFiles.ReloadFile_Selected
member.summary: (Value: 1) Reloads any file selected in a SequenceFileView Manager control.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ReloadFiles.ReloadFile_All
member.summary: (Value: 2) Reloads all files.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBox
member.summary: Connect a SequenceFileView Manager or ExecutionView Manager control to a ListBox control so users can view or select from a list of sequence files, sequences, step groups, steps, executions, threads, or stack frames. Connect an Application Manager control to a ListBox control so users can view or select the default adapter of the TestStand Engine. Use a ListBox control to display multiple pages, where each page contains a list of items that users can view or select. Use the ListBox control to connect to and display the ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ExecutionList, ExecutionViewMgrConnections.CallStack, and ExecutionViewMgrConnections.ThreadList properties in the ExecutionView Manager control and the SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceList, SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.SequenceFileList, and SequenceFileViewMgrConnections.StepGroupList properties in the SequenceFileView Manager control. Selecting an item in the ListBox control updates the application according to the type of connection.

Selecting an item in the ListBox control updates the application according to the type of connection.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of items in the listbox.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the index of the item at the given coordinates. Returns -1 when no item exists at the specified coordinates.
member.remarks: Use this method to determine the item at the given coordinates. For example, when a user clicks on the control, you can determine the item the user clicked.
member.returns: Returns a numeric item index.
member.param: Specifies the x-coordinate of the location to test, in pixels, relative to the control.
Specifies the y-coordinate of the location to test, in pixels, relative to the control.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.HitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the index of the item at the given coordinates. Returns -1 when no item exists at the specified coordinates.
member.remarks: Use this method to determine the item at the given coordinates. For example, when a user clicks on the control, you can determine the item the user clicked.
member.returns: Returns a numeric item index.
member.param: Specifies the x-coordinate of the location to test, in pixels, relative to the control.
Specifies the y-coordinate of the location to test, in pixels, relative to the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.EditingFlags
member.summary: Specifies the types of editing the listbox allows. Use any combination of the EditingFlags constants with this property.
member.remarks: By default, TestStand allows all editing types. These flags have no effect if the listbox is not connected to display editable items.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.EditingFlags
member.summary: Specifies the types of editing the listbox allows. Use any combination of the EditingFlags constants with this property.
member.remarks: By default, TestStand allows all editing types. These flags have no effect if the listbox is not connected to display editable items.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.Enabled
member.summary: The control responds to user input only when this property is True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.Enabled
member.summary: The control responds to user input only when this property is True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.MousePointer
member.summary: Specifies the appearance of the mouse cursor when the cursor is over the control.
member.remarks: When the parameter is MousePointer_Custom, the mouse cursor is the picture the ListBox.MouseIcon property specifies.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.MousePointer
member.summary: Specifies the appearance of the mouse cursor when the cursor is over the control.
member.remarks: When the parameter is MousePointer_Custom, the mouse cursor is the picture the ListBox.MouseIcon property specifies.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.MouseIcon
member.summary: Specifies a custom mouse pointer icon for the control.
member.remarks:
The control displays the specified picture as the cursor when the value of the ListBox.MousePointer property is MousePointer_Custom. When you set this property to NULL, the value of the ListBox.MousePointer property changes to MousePointer_Default.
Note: This property requires that the picture value is an icon.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.MouseIcon
member.summary: Specifies a custom mouse pointer icon for the control.
member.remarks:
The control displays the specified picture as the cursor when the value of the ListBox.MousePointer property is MousePointer_Custom. When you set this property to NULL, the value of the ListBox.MousePointer property changes to MousePointer_Default.
Note: This property requires that the picture value is an icon.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.Font
member.summary: Specifies the font for the control when the value of the ListBox.FontSource property is FontSource_UseFontProperty.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.Font
member.summary: Specifies the font for the control when the value of the ListBox.FontSource property is FontSource_UseFontProperty.

member.summary: Specifies the background color for the control.

member.summary: Specifies the background color for the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.ItemIndex
member.summary:
Specifies the index of the currently selected item in the control.
Note: You cannot change this property at design time.
member.remarks: When no item is selected, the value of this property is -1.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.ItemIndex
member.summary:
Specifies the index of the currently selected item in the control.
Note: You cannot change this property at design time.
member.remarks: When no item is selected, the value of this property is -1.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.Columns
member.summary: TestStand 4.0 or later does not support setting this property to create multiple columns. Setting this property has no effect.
member.remarks: Use the ListBox.ColumnSet property to access information about list box columns.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty if you expect the font the ListBox.Font property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.FontSource
member.summary: Specifies the font the control uses. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseGUIFont.

For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface Controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.ScaleWithDPI

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ListBoxEvents_Event.BorderDragged
member.summary: Occurs when the user drags a draggable border of a control with the mouse. The event provides the location and size to which you must set the control for the draggable borders to track the mouse cursor. However, you can choose to modify the location or size to which you set the control. For example, you can limit the width of the control so the left edge cannot be dragged off of the visible portion of the window. In addition to changing the size and position of the control, you might also update the sizes and positions of the other controls on the window to account for the change.
member.remarks: If you are using LabVIEW, you must add the Horizontal and Vertical components of the origin of the LabVIEW front panel to the newX and newY event parameter values before you can use the newX and newY event parameters to set the ActiveX Container (AxCont) Left and Top properties for the control. To obtain the origin of a LabVIEW front panel, place an ActiveX property node on the block diagram of the VI, right-click the node, and select Link to»Pane from the context menu. Right-click the node again and select Select Property»Origin.
member.param: Specifies which borders the user dragged. Refer to the WhichBorders constants for more information about draggable borders.
Specifies the new x-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new y-coordinate for the control.
Specifies the new width for the control.
Specifies the new height for the control.
Specifies whether the event is the final event for the drag operation the user performs.

member.name: E:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI._ListBoxEvents_Event.CreateContextMenu
member.summary: Occurs when you right-click the control so the application can build a context menu from which you can select commands. Even though you can implement context menus in most environments without using this event, some environments do not provide any other way to create a context menu. Also, creating a context menu using this event is less complicated in most environments, especially when the context menu contains only TestStand commands.
member.param:
Specifies the Microsoft Windows menu handle (HMENU). When you add menu items to the menu handle, the control displays them in a context menu. Use the Commands.InsertIntoWin32Menu method to insert TestStand commands into the menu.
You can also use the menu functions in the Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) to add other menu items; however, these menu items do not have an associated TestStand command. When you select an item without a TestStand command, the control creates and executes a Command object of kind CommandKind_Custom. The control stores the menu item identifier, such as resource ID or command ID, as a long in the Command.UserData property, and as a decimal string in the command display name. You can handle either the ApplicationMgr.PreCommandExecute or ApplicationMgr.PostCommandExecute event to receive a notification when the user selects a menu item you insert with the Windows SDK.
When you close the context menu, the control disposes of the menu items. You do not need to dispose of the menu items you insert.
Specifies the horizontal position of right-clicking, relative to the control.
Specifies the vertical position of right-clicking, relative to the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IListBox.AutoSizeColumns
member.summary: Specifies whether to make all columns fit within the width of the control. When the control resizes, the width of each column for which the ListBoxColumn.Autosizing property is a value other than AutoSizingOption_None adjusts so the columns fit the new size of the control. You must ensure that at least one column enables autosizing when you set this property to True.
member.remarks: When this property is True, the sum of all column widths always equals the width of the control, and the horizontal scrollbar is not visible. When this property is False, you can resize the columns to any width, and the horizontal scrollbar appears as needed. When the value of the autosize property for each column is AutoSizingOption_None, the last column is autosized to fit the width of the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ListBoxClass.AutoSizeColumns
member.summary: Specifies whether to make all columns fit within the width of the control. You must ensure that at least one column enables autosizing when you set this property to True.
member.remarks: When this property is True, the sum of all column widths always equals the width of the control, and the horizontal scrollbar is not visible. When this property is False, you can resize the columns to any width, and the horizontal scrollbar appears as needed. When the value of the autosize property for each column is AutoSizingOption_None, the last column is autosized to fit the width of the control.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ILabel.WordWrap
member.summary: When this property is True, the Label can display multiple lines of text, and the Label breaks lines before a word that would extend past the right edge of the control. When this property is False, the Label always displays one line of text.
member.remarks: When this property is True, the Label.AutoSize property causes the Label to expand vertically. When this property is False, the Label.AutoSize property causes the Label to expand horizontally.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.LabelClass.WordWrap

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ILabel.UseMnemonic
member.summary: The label interprets the character that follows an ampersand (&) character in the Label.Caption property as an accelerator character when this property is True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.LabelClass.UseMnemonic
member.summary: The label interprets the character that follows an ampersand (&) character in the Label.Caption property as an accelerator character when this property is True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ILabel.Caption
member.summary: Specifies the text the control displays.
member.remarks: Use this property to assign an accelerator character to a control when the Label.UseMnemonic property is True. In the caption, include an ampersand (&) immediately before the character you want to designate as the accelerator character. The character is now underlined. Press <Alt> plus the underlined character to move the focus to the control. To include an ampersand in a caption without creating an accelerator character, include two ampersands (&&). A single ampersand is visible in the caption and no characters are underlined.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.LabelClass.Caption

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ILabel.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the text caption.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the caption for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the caption with the string from the .ini file. If the caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect this control to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.LabelClass.Localize(System.String)
member.summary: Localizes the text caption.
member.remarks:
First, update a .ini file located in the TestStand Language directory with the required string. Second, use the string tag in the .ini file as the caption for the control. When you call this method, the control replaces the caption with the string from the .ini file. If the caption is not a tag in the .ini file, the caption does not change.
Note: When you connect this control to a manager control, the manager control automatically sets a localized caption.
member.param: Specifies the name of the section in the language files that contains the localized text.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IReportView.UpdateFromExecution(NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.API.Execution)
member.summary: Updates the content of the control from an Execution object.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IReportView.TextReportFontSource
member.summary:
Specifies the font the control uses to display text reports.
Note: This property does not apply to HTML and XML reports. The default value for this property is FontSource_UseSystemFixedWidthFont.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is FontSource_UseFontProperty, the corresponding Font property specifies the particular font the control uses. Otherwise, the control uses the font from the source this property specifies. Refer to the FontSources enumeration for the list of valid font sources. Set this property to a value other than FontSource_UseFontProperty when you expect the font the ReportView.TextReportFont property specifies to not be present on a computer at run time. For example, a font present on an English version of the Microsoft Windows operating system might not be present on a Japanese version of the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.IReportView.ScaleWithDPI
member.summary: Specifies how the control scales based on the dots per inch (DPI) setting.
member.remarks:
Some environments scale native controls based on the DPI settings of their display, while other environments do not. The TestStand User Interface Controls are designed to work in all environments. The following are the recommended settings for various platforms:
* LabVIEW, LabWindows/CVI, C#, and Microsoft Visual Basic .NET—Set this property to False.
* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.TestStand.Interop.UI.ReportViewClass.ScaleWithDPI

* Active Template Library (ATL)/Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)—Set this property to True.
